title: 103_s1944
content: The Act may be cited as the "Health Care Fraud and Abuse Act of 1994" and includes an expansion of civil and criminal monetary sanctions. The "Health Care Fraud and Abuse Act of 1994" increases civil sanctions under Section 1128A of the Social Security Act, raising the maximum penalty amounts to $5,000 and allowing for adjustments for inflation every five years. The schedule of maximum authorized penalties under the "Health Care Fraud and Abuse Act of 1994" is adjusted every five years based on the cost-of-living adjustment, rounding to the nearest multiple of $1,000. The adjustment is calculated by comparing the Consumer Price Index for the month of June of the previous year to the month of June when the penalty was last adjusted. The amendments to the Social Security Act include treble damages for violations in addition to fines, effective January 1, 1995. SEC. 3. Application of federal health anti-fraud and abuse sanctions to all fraud and abuse against any health benefit plan. Section 1128A of the Social Security Act is amended to include penalties for fraud against health benefit plans, requiring repayment of recovered amounts to the plan. Section 1128B of the Social Security Act is amended to include penalties for fraud against health benefit plans, with specific changes made to subsections (a)(1) and (a)(5) to reflect this addition. The Social Security Act is amended to include penalties for fraud against health benefit plans, with changes made to subsections to reflect this addition. The Social Security Act is amended to include penalties for fraud against health benefit plans, with changes made to subsections to reflect this addition. The term "health benefit plan" is defined for purposes of sections 1128A and 1128B as a health benefit program other than Medicare, Medicaid, or a State health care program. The Social Security Act is amended to include penalties for fraud against health benefit plans, with changes made to subsections to reflect this addition. The term "health benefit plan" is defined as a health benefit program other than Medicare, Medicaid, or a State health care program. Section 1128(b)(8)(B)(ii) is amended to specify penalties arising from a health benefit plan. The amendments made by this section will take effect on January 1, 1995. SEC. 4. Civil monetary penalties included in anti-kickback sanctions. Section 1128A(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include penalties for activities violating section 1128B(b). The penalties include fines of $5,000 for each item or service in certain cases, $15,000 for each individual in other cases. The Social Security Act is amended to include penalties for violations of section 1128B(b), with fines ranging from $5,000 to $15,000 per violation. Effective date of the amendments is January 1, 1995. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Attorney General, will establish a voluntary disclosure program within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. This program aims to encourage disclosures of potential violations of health care fraud and abuse laws by offering reduced penalties for voluntary disclosures. Expansion of health care fraud investigative resources by authorizing $25,000,000 for additional personnel in the Department of Health and Human Services Office of the Inspector General for fiscal years 1994-1997.
